name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: [SOUND].

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: This lecture is about recommender systems.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _So
column6: so far we have talked about a lot of aspects of search engines. _

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _And we have talked about the problem of search and the ranking problem

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _different methods for ranking
column6: implementation of search engine and _

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _how to evaluate the search engine
column6: et cetera. _

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _This is partly because we know that web search engines are

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _by far
column6: the most important applications of text retrieval. _

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: And they are the most useful tools to help people convert big raw text

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: data into a small set of relevant documents.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: Another reason why we spend so many lectures on search engines is because

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: many techniques used in search engines are actually also very useful for

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _recommender systems
column6: which is the topic of this lecture. _

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _And so overall the two systems are actually well connected

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: and there are many techniques that are shared by them.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: So this is a slide that you have seen before when we talked about

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: the two different modes of text access pull and push.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _And
column6: we mentioned that recommender systems are the main systems to serve _

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _users in the push mode
column6: where the systems will take the initiative to _

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _recommend the information to user
column6: or to push the relevant information to the user. _

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _And this often works well when the user has a relatively stable information need

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: when the system has good knowledge about what a user wants.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: So a recommender system is sometimes called a filtering system.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: And it's because recommending useful items to people is like

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: discarding or filtering out the useless articles.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _So in this sense
column6: they are kind of similar. _

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _And in all the cases
column6: the system must make a binary decision. _

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _And usually
column6: there is a dynamic source of information items

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _and you have some knowledge about the user's interest
column6: and then the system would _

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _make a delivery decision
column6: whether this item is interesting to the user. _

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: And then if it is interesting then the system would recommend the article to

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: the user.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _So the basic filtering question here is really
column6: will this user like

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: Will U like item X?

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _And there are two ways to answer this question if you think about it
column6: right? _

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _One is look at what items U likes
column6: and _

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: then we can see if X is actually like those items.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _The other is to look at who likes X
column6: and we can see if this user looks like a

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _one of those users
column6: or like most of those users. _

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: And these strategies can be combined.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: If we follow the first strategy and

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _look at item similarity in the case of recommended text objects

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: then we are talking about a content-based filtering or content-based recommendation.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _If we look at the second strategy then
column6: this will compare users. _

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _And in this case
column6: we're exploiting user similarity

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: and the technique is often called a collaborative filtering.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: So let's first look at the content-based filtering system.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: This is what a system would look like.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _Inside the system
column6: there would be a binary classifier that would have some _

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _knowledge about the user's interests
column6: and it's called the user interest profile. _

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: It maintains the profile to keep track of the user's interest.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _And then there is a utility function to guide the user to make decisions
column6: and _

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: I'll explain the utility of the function in a moment.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: It helps the system decide where to set the threshold.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: And then the accepted documents will be those that have passed

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: the threshold according to the classifier.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _There should be also an initialization module that would take a user's input

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _maybe from a user's
column6: specified keywords

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _And this will be
column6: to feed the system with a initial user profile. _

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: There is also typically a learning module that will learn from

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: users' feedback over time.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _Now note that in this case
column6: typically users' information need is stable so _

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _the system would have a lot of opportunities to observe the users

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _you know
column6: if the user has taken a recommended item as viewed that

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _this is a cu
column6: a signal to indicate that the recommended item may be relevant. _

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _If the user discarded it
column6: no

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _And so
column6: such feedback can be a long-term feedback and can last for a long time and _

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _the system can clock
column6: collect a lot of information about this user's interests. _

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: And this can then be used to improve the classifier.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: Now whats the criteria for evaluating such a system?

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: How do we know this filtering system actually performs well?

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _Now in this case we cannot use the ranking evaluation measures
column6: like a map

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _because we can't afford waiting for a lot of documents

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: and then rank the documents to make a decision for the user.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _And so
column6: the system must make a decision

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: in general to decide whether the item is above the threshold or not.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _So in other words
column6: we're trying to decide absolute relevance. _

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: So in this case one common use strategy is to use a utility function

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: through a valid system.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _So here I show a linear utility function that's defined as
column6: for example

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _3 multiplied by the number of good items that you delivered

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _minus 2 multiplied by the number of bad items you delete
column6: that you delivered. _

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _So in other words
column6: we

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _treat this as almost a
column6: in a gambling game. _

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _If you delete
column6: if you deliver one good item

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _let's say you win $3
column6: you gain $3. _

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _But if you deliver a bad one
column6: you would lose $2. _

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _And this utility function basically kind of measures

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _how much money you would
column6: get by doing this kind of game

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _And so it's clear that if you want to maximize this utility function

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _your strategy should be to deliver as many good articles as possible

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: and minimize the delivery of bad articles.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _That
column6: that's obvious

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _Now one interesting question here is
column6: how should we set these coefficients? _

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _Now I just showed a 3 and a negative 2

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _as the possible coefficients
column6: but one can ask the question

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: So what do you think?

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: Do you think that's a reasonable choice?

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: What about other choices?

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _So for example
column6: we can have 10 and minus 1

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: What's the difference?

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: What do you think?

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: How would this utility function affect the system's threshold of this issue?

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _Right
column6: you can think of these two extreme cases

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: Which one do we think it would encourage the system to over-deliver?

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: And which one would encourage the system to be conservative?

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: Yeah?

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _If you think about it
column6: you will see that when we get a big award for _

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _delivering a good document
column6: you incur only a small penalty for delivering a bad one. _

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _Intuitively
column6: you would be encouraging to deliver more

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _And you can try to deliver more in hope of getting a good one delivered
column6: and _

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: then you'll get a big award.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _Right
column6: so on the other hand

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: you don't really get such a big prize if you deliver a good document.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _On the other hand
column6: you will have a big loss if you deliver bad one. _

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: You can imagine that the system would be very reluctant to

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: deliver lot of documents.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: It has to be absolutely sure that it's a non-relevant one.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: So this utility function has to be designed based on a specific application.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: The three basic problems in content-based filtering are the following.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: First has to make a filtering decision.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _So it has to be a binary decision maker
column6: a binary classifier. _

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _Given a text
column6: a text document
column7: and a profile description of the user

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _it has to say yes or no
column6: whether this document should be delivered or not. _

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _So that's a decision module
column6: and _

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: there should be a initialization module as you have seen earlier.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: And this is to get the system started.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _And we have to initialize the system based on only very limited text description

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: or very few examples from the user.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _And the third component is a learning module which ha

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: has to be able to learn from limited relevance judgments because we

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: can only learn from the user about their preferences on the delivery documents.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _If we don't deliver a document to the user
column6: we'd never know _

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _we would never be able to know whether the user likes it or not
column6: right. _

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _And we can accumulate a lot of documents
column6: we can learn from the entire history. _

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _Now
column6: all these models would have to be optimized to maximize the utility. _

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: So how can we build a such a system?

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: And there are many different approaches.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _Here we are going to talk about how to extend a retrieval system

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: a search engine for information filtering.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _Again
column6: here's why we've spent a lot of times talk about the search engines. _

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: Because it's actually not very hard to extend the search engine for

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: information filtering.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _So
column6: here is the basic idea for extending a retrieval system for _

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: information filtering.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _First
column6: we can reuse a lot of retrieval techniques to do scoring. _

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _All right
column6: so we know how to score documents against queries et cetera. _

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: We can measure the similarity between a profile text description and a document.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: And then we can use a score threshold for the filtering decision.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _We
column6: we do retrieval and then we kind of find the scores of documents

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _then we apply a threshold to
column6: to say

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: to see whether a document is passing this threshold or not.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _And if it's passing the threshold
column6: we are going to say it's relevant and _

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: we are going to deliver it to the user.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _And another component that we have to add is
column6: of course

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: And here we can use the traditional feedback techniques

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: to learn to improve scoring.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _And we know Rocchio can be used for scoring improvement
column6: right? _

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _And
column6: but we have to develop new approaches to learn how to set the threshold. _

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _And you know
column6: we need to set it initially

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: then we have to learn how to update the threshold over time.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: So here's what the system might look like if we just

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _generalized a vector-space model for filtering problems
column6: right? _

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _So you can see the document vector could be fed into a scoring module
column6: which it _

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: already exists in in a search engine that implements a vector-space model.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: And the profile will be treated as a query essentially.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _And then the profile vector can be matched with the document vector

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: to generate the score.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: And then this score will be fed into a thresholding module that would

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: say yes or no.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: And then the evaluation would be based on the utility for the filtering results.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _If it says yes
column6: and then the document will be sent to the user

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: then the user could give some feedback.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: _And the feedback information would have been use
column6: would be used to both _

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: adjust to the threshold and adjust the vector representation.

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: So the vector learning is essentially the same as query modification or

name: 5 - 10 - 4.6 Recommender Systems- Content-based Filtering - Part 1  (00-12-55).srt
text: feedback in the case of search.
